sen.j: 酉の市（とりのいち）は、例年11月の酉に行われる、各地の鷲神社（おおとりじんじゃ）の祭。
sen.e: "Tori no ichi" is an open-market fair held at Otori-jinja Shrines around the country on the Days of the Cock in November every year.
"Tori no ichi" is an open-market fair held at Otori-jinja Shrines around the country on the Days of the Cock in November every year.
"Tori no ichi" is an open-market fair held at Otori-jinja Shrines around the country on the Days of the Cock in November every year.

sen.j: 古くは酉の祭（とりのまち）と呼ばれた。
sen.e: In ancient times, it was called Tori no machi.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: In ancient times, it was called Tori no machi.
In ancient times, it was called Tori no machi.

sen.j: また、大酉祭、お酉様とも呼ばれる。
sen.e: Its other names include Otori-sai and Otori-sama.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: Its other names include Otori-sai and Otori-sama.
Its other names include Otori-sai and Otori-sama.

sen.j: 酉の市で縁起物を買う風習は、関東地方特有の年中行事。
sen.e: The tradition of buying lucky charms in Tori no ichi is an annual event unique to the Kanto region.
The tradition of buying lucky charms in Tori no ichi is an annual event unique to the Kanto region.

sen.j: 概説

sen.j: 鷲神社は、ヤマトタケル（やまとたけるのみこと）を祀る。
sen.e: Otori-jinja Shrines enshrine Yamato Takeru (also called Yamato Takeru no Mikoto, which means Prince Yamato Takeru).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: Otori-jinja Shrines enshrine Yamato Takeru (also called Yamato Takeru no Mikoto, which means Prince Yamato Takeru).
Otori-jinja Shrines enshrine Yamato Takeru (also called Yamato Takeru no Mikoto, which means Prince Yamato Takeru).

sen.j: 武運長久、開運、商売繁盛の神として信仰される。
sen.e: He is worshiped as the god of long-lasting good luck in a battle, better fortune, and success in business.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: He is worshiped as the deity of long-lasting good luck in battle, better fortune, and success in business.
sen.cmt: god→deity と修正しました。a を削除しました。
sen.e: He is worshiped as the deity of long-lasting good luck in battle, better fortune, and success in business.

sen.j: 近畿地方では大鳥大社（大阪府堺市西区 (堺市)）が本社とされる。
sen.e: In the Kinki region, Otori Taisha Shrine (in Nishi Ward, Sakai City, Osaka Prefecture) is said to be the main shrine.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: In the Kinki region, Otori Taisha Shrine (in Nishi Ward, Sakai City, Osaka Prefecture) is said to be the main shrine.
In the Kinki region, Otori Taisha Shrine (in Nishi Ward, Sakai City, Osaka Prefecture) is said to be the main shrine.

sen.j: しかし、関東各地にある鷲神社との関係は明らかでない。
sen.e: However, it is not clear how it relates to Otori-jinja Shrines throughout the Kanto region.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: However, it is not clear how it relates to Otori-jinja Shrines throughout the Kanto region.

sen.j: 関東では、鷲宮神社（埼玉県北葛飾郡鷲宮町）が鷲神社の本社とされる。
sen.e: In the Kanto region, Washinomiya-jinja Shrine (in Washinomiya Town, Kitakatsushika County, Saitama Prefecture) is said to be the main shrine of Otori-jinja Shrines.
In the Kanto region, Washinomiya-jinja Shrine (in Washimiya-machi, Kitakatsushika-gun, Saitama Prefecture) is said to be the main shrine of Otori-jinja Shrines.
sen.cmt: Washinomiya Town, Kitakatsushika County→Washimiya-machi, Kitakatsushika-gun と修正しました。
sen.e: In the Kanto region, Washinomiya-jinja Shrine (in Washimiya-machi, Kitakatsushika-gun, Saitama Prefecture) is said to be the main shrine of Otori-jinja Shrines.

sen.j: 鷲宮神社の祭神は、天穂日命、武夷鳥命、大己貴命である。
sen.e: Its enshrined deities are Ame no Hohi no Mikoto, Takehinadori no Mikoto, and Onamuchi no Mikoto.
Its enshrined deities are Ame no Hohi no Mikoto, Takehinadori no Mikoto, and Onamuchi no Mikoto.
Its enshrined deities are Ame no Hohi no Mikoto, Takehinadori no Mikoto, and Onamuchi no Mikoto.

sen.j: 日本武尊が東征の際、この神社で戦勝を祈願したとされる。
sen.e: It is said that Yamato Takeru no Mikoto prayed for a victory at this shrine when he went to the east.
It is said that Yamato Takeru no Mikoto prayed for a victory at this shrine when he went to the east.
It is said that Yamato Takeru no Mikoto prayed for a victory at this shrine when he went to the east.

sen.j: 古くからこの神社を中心に「酉の日精進」の信仰が広まった。
sen.e: The traditional belief of "Tori no hi shojin" (abstinence on Tori no hi (the Days of the Cock)) spread around this shrine.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: The traditional belief of 'Tori no hi shojin' (abstinence on Tori no hi [the Days of the Cock]) spread around this shrine.
sen.cmt: クォーツ、カッコを修正しました
sen.e: The traditional belief of 'Tori no hi shojin' (abstinence on Tori no hi [the Days of the Cock]) spread around this shrine.

sen.j: そして、12月の初酉の日には大酉祭が行われる。
sen.e: And Otori-sai is held on the first Tori no hi in December.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: And Otori-sai is held on the first Tori no hi in December.
And Otori-sai is held on the first Tori no hi in December.

sen.j: 江戸時代には、武蔵国南足立郡花又村（現・東京都足立区花畑 (足立区)）にある大鷲神社 (東京都足立区)（鷲大明神）が栄えた。
sen.e: In the Edo period, Otori-jinja Shrine (which enshrines Otori Daimyojin (the Great Eagle God)) in Hanamata Village, Minami Adachi County, Musashi Province (which is present Hanahata, Adachi Ward, Tokyo Prefecture) thrived.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: In the Edo period, Otori-jinja Shrine (which enshrines Otori Daimyojin [the Great Eagle God]) in Hanamata Village, Minami Adachi County, Musashi Province (which is present Hanahata, Adachi Ward, Tokyo Metropolis) thrived.
sen.cmt: カッコを修正しました。Tokyo Prefecture→Tokyo Metropolis と修正しました。
sen.e: In the Edo period, Otori-jinja Shrine (which enshrines Otori Daimyojin [the Great Eagle God]) in Hanamata Village, Minami Adachi County, Musashi Province (which is present Hanahata, Adachi Ward, Tokyo) thrived.

sen.j: 「本酉」と言われた。
sen.e: Its Tori no ichi was called 'Hontori' (the Main Cock).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: Its Tori no ichi was called 'Hontori' (the Main Cock).
Its Tori no ichi was called 'Hontori' (the Main Cock).

sen.j: この花又鷲大明神を産土神とする近在住民の収穫祭が江戸酉の市の発端といわれている。
sen.e: The harvest festival held by the residents of neighboring towns and villages, who worshiped the Otori Daimyojin in Hanamata as ubusuna-gami (the guardian deity of one's birthplace), is said to be the origin of Tori no ichi in Edo.

The harvest festival held by the residents of neighboring towns and villages, who worshiped the Otori Daimyojin in Hanamata as ubusuna-gami (the guardian deity of one's birthplace), is said to be the origin of Tori no ichi in Edo.

sen.j: 現在の大鷲神社の祭神は日本武尊。
sen.e: The present enshrined deity of the Otroi-jinja Shrine is Yamato Takeru no Mikoto.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: The present enshrined deity of the Otroi-jinja Shrine is Yamato Takeru no Mikoto.
The present enshrined deity of the Otroi-jinja Shrine is Yamato Takeru no Mikoto.

sen.j: 東征からの帰還の際、同地で戦勝を祝したとされる。
sen.e: He is said to have celebrated a victory at the shrine when he returned from going to the east.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: He is said to have celebrated a victory at the shrine when he returned from going to the east.
He is said to have celebrated a victory at the shrine when he returned from going to the east.

sen.j: 江戸時代には、大鷲神社の本尊（神仏習合本地垂迹説）は鷲の背に乗った釈迦とされた。
sen.e: It was believed in the Edo period that the principal image of the Otori-jinja Shrine was Shaka (a Buddha) standing on the back of an eagle (on the basis of the honji-suijaku-setsu (the theory of original reality and manifested traces, according to which Shinto gods are manifestations of Buddhas) under the concept of shinbutsu-shugo (the syncretism of Shinto and Buddhism)).

It was believed in the Edo period that the principal image of the Otori-jinja Shrine was Shaka (Buddha) standing on the back of an eagle (on the basis of the honji-suijaku-setsu [the theory of original reality and manifested traces, according to which Shinto gods are manifestations of Buddhas] under the concept of shinbutsu-shugo [the syncretism of Shinto and Buddhism]).
sen.cmt: a Buddha→Buddha,カッコをそれぞれ修正しました。
sen.e: It was believed in the Edo period that the principal image of the Otori-jinja Shrine was Shaka (Buddha) standing on the back of an eagle (on the basis of the honji-suijaku-setsu [the theory of original reality and manifested traces, according to which Shinto gods are manifestations of Buddhas] under the concept of shinbutsu-shugo [the syncretism of Shinto and Buddhism]).

sen.j: 大鷲神社の酉の市は、15世紀初めの応永年間に始まるとされる。
sen.e: The Tori no ichi of the Otori-jinja Shrine is believed to have begun during the Oei era at the beginning of the 15th century.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: The Tori no ichi of the Otori-jinja Shrine is believed to have begun during the Oei era at the beginning of the 15th century.
The Tori no ichi of the Otori-jinja Shrine is believed to have begun during the Oei era at the beginning of the 15th century.

sen.j: 参詣人は、ニワトリを献納して開運を祈った。
sen.e: The visitors to the shrine prayed for better luck by offering chickens.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: The visitors to the shrine prayed for better luck by offering chickens.
The visitors to the shrine prayed for better luck by offering chickens.

sen.j: そして、祭が終了した後浅草観音堂前（浅草寺）に献納した鶏を放った
sen.e: When the festival was over, they released them in front of Asakusa Kannon-do (the main hall of Senso-ji Temple, in which Kannon (the Goddess of Mercy) was housed, in Asakusa).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: When the festival was over, they released them in front of Asakusa Kannon Do (the temple dedicated to Kannon in Asakusa) (Senso-ji Temple).
sen.cmt: 後半部分を修正しました。
sen.e: When the festival was over, they released them in front of Asakusa Kannon Do (the temple dedicated to Kannon in Asakusa) (Senso-ji Temple).

sen.j: 江戸時代後期から、最も著名な酉の市は、浅草の鷲在山長国寺（じゅざいさん・ちょうこくじ、法華宗本門流）境内の鷲大明神社（東京都台東区千束）で行われた酉の市である。
sen.e: The most prominent Tori no ichi since the late Edo period has been the one held at Otori Daimyojin no Yashiro Shrine in the precincts of Juzaisan Chokoku-ji Temple (which belongs to the Honmon Lineage of the Hokke Sect) in Asakusa (in Senzoku, Taito Ward, Tokyo Prefecture).

The most prominent Tori no ichi since the late Edo period has been the one held at Otori Daimyojin no Yashiro Shrine in the precincts of Juzaisan Chokoku-ji Temple (which belongs to the Honmon Lineage of the Hokke Sect) in Asakusa (in Senzoku, Taito Ward, Tokyo Metropolis).
sen.cmt: ”鷲在山長国寺”については、用語統一57項に当てはまるのかどうか定かでありませんでした。Tokyo Metropolis と修正しました。
sen.e: The most prominent Tori no ichi since the late Edo period has been the one held at Otori Daimyojin no Yashiro Shrine in the precincts of Juzaisan Chokoku-ji Temple (which belongs to the Honmon Lineage of the Hokke Sect) in Asakusa (in Senzoku, Taito Ward, Tokyo).

sen.j: 「本酉」「大酉」と呼ばれた花又の酉の市に対して「新酉」と呼ばれた。
sen.e: In contrast to Tori no ichi in Hanamata, which was called 'Hontori' (the Main Cock) or 'Otori' (the Great Cock), it was called 'Shintori' (the New Cock).
In contrast to Tori no ichi in Hanamata, which was called 'Hontori' (the Main Cock) or 'Otori' (the Great Cock), it was called 'Shintori' (the New Cock).
In contrast to Tori no ichi in Hanamata, which was called 'Hontori' (the Main Cock) or 'Otori' (the Great Cock), it was called 'Shintori' (the New Cock).

sen.j: 当時浅草の鷲大明神は妙見大菩薩（みょうけんだいぼさつ。）とも呼ばれていた。
sen.e: At that time, the Otori Daimyojin of Asakusa was also called Myoken Daibosatsu.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: At that time, the Otori Daimyojin of Asakusa was also called Myoken Daibosatsu.
At that time, the Otori Daimyojin of Asakusa was also called Myoken Daibosatsu.

sen.j: そして、鷲に乗った妙見菩薩の姿として描かれ、長国寺境内の番神堂（鷲大明神社）に安置された。
sen.e: It was depicted as Myoken Bosatsu standing on the back of an eagle, and it was set in place in Banjin-do (which was Otori Daimyojin no Yashiro Shrine) in the precincts of Chokoku-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: Then, it was depicted as Myoken Bosatsu standing on the back of an eagle, and set in place in Banjin-do (which was Otori Daimyojin no Yashiro Shrine) in the precincts of Chokoku-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: Thenを挿入しました。it was を削除しました。
sen.e: Then, it was depicted as Myoken Bosatsu standing on the back of an eagle, and set in place in Banjin-do (which was Otori Daimyojin no Yashiro Shrine) in the precincts of Chokoku-ji Temple.

sen.j: 11月の酉の日には鷲妙見大菩薩が開帳され、酉の市が盛大に行われるようになる。
sen.e: On Tori no hi in November, Washi Myoken Daibosatsu was unveiled, and Tori no ichi began to be held on a grand scale.
On Tori no hi in November, Washi Myoken Daibosatsu was unveiled, and Tori no ichi began to be held on a grand scale.
On Tori no hi in November, Washi Myoken Daibosatsu was unveiled, and Tori no ichi began to be held on a grand scale.

sen.j: 鷲大明神社は「鷲宮（わしのみや）」、長国寺は「酉の寺」とも呼ばれた。
sen.e: Otori Daimyojin no Yashiro Shrine was also called 'Washi no Miya' (the Eagle Shrine), and Chokoku-ji Temple 'Tori no Tera' (the Cock Temple).
Otori Daimyojin no Yashiro Shrine and Chokoku-ji Temple were also called 'Washi no Miya' (the Eagle Shrine), and 'Tori no Tera' (the Cock Temple).
sen.cmt: 流れをよりスムースにしました。
sen.e: Otori Daimyojin no Yashiro Shrine and Chokoku-ji Temple were also called 'Washi no Miya' (the Eagle Shrine), and 'Tori no Tera' (the Cock Temple).

sen.j: 明治初年には神仏分離令により、長国寺と鷲神社とに引き分けられた。
sen.e: During the first years of the Meiji period, they were separated into Chokoku-ji Temple and Otori-jinja Shrine by the Edict of Separation of Shinto and Buddhism.
At the first year of the Meiji period, they were separated into Chokoku-ji Temple and Otori-jinja Shrine by the Edict of Separation of Shinto and Buddhism.
sen.cmt: During the first years→At the first year
sen.e: At the first year of the Meiji period, they were separated into Chokoku-ji Temple and Otori-jinja Shrine by the Edict of Separation of Shinto and Buddhism.

sen.j: 現在の鷲神社の祭神は、天日鷲命と日本武尊。
sen.e: The present enshrined deities of the Otori-jinja Shrine are Ame no Hiwashi no Mikoto and Yamato Takeru no Mikoto.
The present enshrined deities of the Otori-jinja Shrine are Ame no Hiwashi no Mikoto and Yamato Takeru no Mikoto.
The present enshrined deities of the Otori-jinja Shrine are Ame no Hiwashi no Mikoto and Yamato Takeru no Mikoto.

sen.j: この「本酉」「新酉」の他、千住の勝専寺（赤門寺。浄土宗）が「中酉」と呼ばれた。
sen.e: Aside from 'Hontori' and 'Shintori,' there was Tori no ichi held in Shosen-ji Temple (Akamon-dera Temple belonging to the Jodo Sect) in Senju, and it was called 'Naka no tori' (the Middle Cock).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: Aside from 'Hontori' and 'Shintori,' there was Tori no ichi held in Shosen-ji Temple (Akamon-dera Temple belonging to the Jodo Sect) in Senju, and it was called 'Naka no tori' (the Middle Cock).
Aside from 'Hontori' and 'Shintori,' there was Tori no ichi held in Shosen-ji Temple (Akamon-dera Temple belonging to the Jodo Sect) in Senju, and it was called 'Naka no tori' (the Middle Cock).

sen.j: それぞれ盛大な酉の市が開かれた。
sen.e: Each of them was a splendid Tori no ichi.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: Each of them was a splendid Tori no ichi.
Each of them was a splendid Tori no ichi.

sen.j: なお、勝専寺の鷲大明神は、鷲の背に乗った釈迦仏の姿をしている。
sen.e: The Otori Daimyojin of Shosen-ji Temple has a form of Shaka Butsu (Sakyamuni Buddha) standing on the back of an eagle.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: The Otori Daimyojin of Shosen-ji Temple has a form of Shaka Butsu (Sakyamuni Buddha) standing on the back of an eagle.
The Otori Daimyojin of Shosen-ji Temple has a form of Shaka Butsu (Sakyamuni Buddha) standing on the back of an eagle.

sen.j: そして、3代将軍・徳川家光から賜ったとされる。
sen.e: It is believed to have been given by Third Shogun Iemitsu TOKUGAWA.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: It is believed to have been given by Third Shogun Iemitsu TOKUGAWA.
It is believed to have been given by Third Shogun Iemitsu TOKUGAWA.

sen.j: 現在、勝専寺では酉の市は行われない。
sen.e: Today, Tori no ichi is not held in Shosen-ji Temple.
Today, Tori no ichi is not held in Shosen-ji Temple.
Today, Tori no ichi is not held in Shosen-ji Temple.

sen.j: 現在では、花園神社（東京都新宿区）、大國魂神社 (府中市)（東京都府中市 (東京都)）、鴻神社（埼玉県鴻巣市）、寂光院（群馬県桐生市）など、関東地方各地の社寺で大鳥神社を勧請し、酉の市が行われている。
sen.e: Now shrines and temples all over the Kanto region, including Hanazono-jinja Shrine (in Shinjuku Ward, Tokyo Metropolis), Okunitama-jinja Shrine (in Fuchu City, Tokyo Metropolis), Ko-jinja Shrine (in Konosu City, Saitama Prefecture), and Jakko-in Temple (in Kiryu City, Gunma Prefecture), enshrine the divided spirit of the enshrined deity of the Otori-jinja Shrine and hold Tori no ichi.

Now, shrines and temples all over the Kanto region, including Hanazono-jinja Shrine (in Shinjuku Ward, Tokyo Metropolis), Okunitama-jinja Shrine (in Fuchu City, Tokyo Metropolis), Ko-jinja Shrine (in Konosu City, Saitama Prefecture), and Jakko-in Temple (in Kiryu City, Gunma Prefecture), enshrine the divided spirit of the enshrined deity of the Otori-jinja Shrine and hold Tori no ichi.
sen.cmt: カンマを挿入しました。
sen.e: Now, shrines and temples all over the Kanto region, including Hanazono-jinja Shrine (in Shinjuku Ward, Tokyo), Okunitama-jinja Shrine (in Fuchu City, Tokyo), Ko-jinja Shrine (in Konosu City, Saitama Prefecture), and Jakko-in Temple (in Kiryu City, Gunma Prefecture), enshrine the divided spirit of the enshrined deity of the Otori-jinja Shrine and hold Tori no ichi.

sen.j: なお、関東地方以外では浜松市の大安寺（静岡県浜松市中区）で酉の市が行われる。
sen.e: Outside the Kanto region, Tori no ichi is held in Daian-ji Temple in Hamamatsu City (in Naka Ward, Hamamatsu City, Shizuoka Prefecture).
Outside the Kanto region, Tori no ichi is held in Daian-ji Temple in Hamamatsu City (in Naka Ward, Hamamatsu City, Shizuoka Prefecture).
Outside the Kanto region, Tori no ichi is held in Daian-ji Temple in Hamamatsu City (in Naka Ward, Hamamatsu City, Shizuoka Prefecture).

sen.j: 近畿地方及び四国地方並びに中京圏などでは、名古屋市の熱田神宮にも見られるとおり歴史的に「えびす講」が主流だ。
sen.e: In the Kinki and Shikoku regions, the Chukyo area, and so on, 'Ebisu-ko' (a festival honoring Ebisu (the God of Wealth) held for the purpose of praying for good harvests, a good catch of fish, and business success), as seen in Atsuta-jingu Shrine in Nagoya City, is historically the mainstream.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: In the Kinki and Shikoku regions, also the Chukyo area, and so on, 'Ebisu-ko' (a festival honoring Ebisu [the God of Wealth] held for the purpose of praying for good harvests, a good catch of fish, and business success), as seen in Atsuta-jingu Shrine in Nagoya City, is historically the mainstream.
sen.cmt: also を挿入しました。カッコを修正しました。
sen.e: In the Kinki and Shikoku regions, also the Chukyo area, and so on, 'Ebisu-ko' (a festival honoring Ebisu [the God of Wealth] held for the purpose of praying for good harvests, a good catch of fish, and business success), as seen in Atsuta-jingu Shrine in Nagoya City, is historically the mainstream.

sen.j: しかし、例外的に素盞男神社で酉の市が行われる他、大須七寺でも行われている。
sen.e: However, Tori no ichi is also held exceptionally in Nanatsu-dera Temple in Osu, in addition to Susanoo-jinja Shrine.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: However, Tori no ichi is also held exceptionally in Nanatsu-dera Temple in Osu, in addition to Susanoo-jinja Shrine.
sen.cmt: スペースの修正をしました。
sen.e: However, Tori no ichi is also held exceptionally in Nanatsu-dera Temple in Osu, in addition to Susanoo-jinja Shrine.

sen.j: なお、「縁起熊手」を売る風習は、全国各地にある。
sen.e: The custom of selling 'engi-kumade' (gook luck rakes) is seen all over Japan.
The custom of selling 'engi-kumade' (gook luck rakes) is seen all over Japan.
The custom of selling 'engi-kumade' (gook luck rakes) is seen all over Japan.

sen.j: 由来
sen.e: Origin
Origin
Origin

sen.j: 酉の市の由来は、神道と仏教の双方から、それぞれ異なる解説がされる。
sen.e: Shinto and Buddhism have different explanations about the origin of Tori no ichi.
Shinto and Buddhism have different explanations about the origin of Tori no ichi.
Shinto and Buddhism have different explanations about the origin of Tori no ichi.

sen.j: 神道の解説では、大酉祭の日に立った市を、酉の市の起源とする。
sen.e: In Shinto, Tori no ichi has its origin in the fair that was held on the day of Otori-sai.
In Shinto, Tori no ichi has its origin in the fair that was held on the day of Otori-sai.
In Shinto, Tori no ichi has its origin in the fair that was held on the day of Otori-sai.

sen.j: 大鳥神社（鷲神社）の祭神である日本武尊が、東征の戦勝祈願を鷲宮神社で行った。
sen.e: The enshrined deity of Otori-jinja Shrines, Yamato Takeru no Mikoto, prayed for a victory in the eastern expedition at Washinomiya-jinja Shrine.
The enshrined deity of Otori-jinja Shrines, Yamato Takeru no Mikoto, prayed for a victory in the eastern expedition at Washinomiya-jinja Shrine.
The enshrined deity of Otori-jinja Shrines, Yamato Takeru no Mikoto, prayed for a victory in the eastern expedition at Washinomiya-jinja Shrine.

sen.j: そして、祝勝を花畑の大鷲神社の地で行った。
sen.e: And he held a victory celebration at Otori-jinja Shrine in Hanamata.
And, he held a victory celebration at Otori-jinja Shrine in Hanahata.
sen.cmt: カンマの挿入,Hanamata→Hanahata と修正しました。
sen.e: And, he held a victory celebration at Otori-jinja Shrine in Hanahata.

sen.j: これにちなみ、日本武尊が亡くなった日とされる11月の酉の日（鷲宮神社では12月の初酉の日）には大酉祭が行われる。
sen.e: In connection with this, Otori-sai is held on Tori no hi in November (or, the first Tori no hi in December in the case of Washinomiya-jinja Shrine), on which Yamato Takeru no Mikoto is believed to have died.

In connection with this, Otori-sai is held on Tori no hi in November (or, the first Tori no hi in December in the case of Washinomiya-jinja Shrine), on which Yamato Takeru no Mikoto is believed to have died.

In connection with this, Otori-sai is held on Tori no hi in November (or, the first Tori no hi in December in the case of Washinomiya-jinja Shrine), on which Yamato Takeru no Mikoto is believed to have died.

sen.j: また、浅草・鷲神社の社伝では、日本武尊が鷲神社に戦勝のお礼参りをしたのが11月の酉の日であり、その際、社前の松に武具の熊手を立て掛けた。
sen.e: According to the biography of Otori-jinja Shrine in Asakusa, Yamato Takeru no Mikoto visited the shrine for thanksgiving on Tori no hi in November and leaned a rake, which was used as a weapon, against the pine tree in front of it.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: According to the biography of Otori-jinja Shrine in Asakusa, Yamato Takeru no Mikoto visited the shrine for thanksgiving on Tori no hi in November, and he leaned a rake, which was used as a weapon, against the pine tree in front of it.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処カンマ, he を挿入しました。
sen.e: According to the biography of Otori-jinja Shrine in Asakusa, Yamato Takeru no Mikoto visited the shrine for thanksgiving on Tori no hi in November, and he leaned a rake, which was used as a weapon, against the pine tree in front of it.

sen.j: そのことから、大酉祭を行い、熊手を縁起物とするとしている。
sen.e: On the basis of this anecdote, Otori-sai is held and a rake is considered a lucky charm.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: On the basis of this anecdote, Otori-sai is held and a rake is considered a lucky charm.
On the basis of this anecdote, Otori-sai is held and a rake is considered a lucky charm.

sen.j: 仏教（浅草酉の寺・長国寺）の解説では、鷲妙見大菩薩の開帳日に立った市を酉の市の起源とする。
sen.e: In the Buddhist account (specifically, that of Tori no tera, Chokoku-ji Temple, in Asakusa), Tori no ichi has its origin in the fair that was held on the day, on which Myoken Daibosatsu was unveiled.
In the Buddhist account (Tori no tera, Chokoku-ji Temple, in Asakusa), Tori no ichi has its origin in the fair that was held on the day, on which Myoken Daibosatsu was unveiled.
sen.cmt: カッコ内を修正しました。
sen.e: In the Buddhist account (Tori no tera, Chokoku-ji Temple, in Asakusa), Tori no ichi has its origin in the fair that was held on the day, on which Myoken Daibosatsu was unveiled.

sen.j: 1265年（文永2年）11月の酉の日、日蓮宗の宗祖・日蓮上人が、上総国鷲巣（現・千葉県茂原市）の小早川家（現・大本山鷲山寺）に滞在の折、国家平穏を祈ったところ、金星が明るく輝きだし、鷲妙見大菩薩が現れ出た。
sen.e: On Tori no hi in November 1265 (in old lunar calendar), when Nichiren Shonin (High Priest Nichiren), the founder of the Nichiren sect, prayed for the national peace during his stay at the Kobayakawa house (which is present Daihonzan (the chief temple of the sect) Jusen-ji Temple) in Washi no su, Kazusa Province (which is present Mobara City, Chiba Prefecture), the Venus started to shine brightly and Washi Myoken Daibosatsu appeared.
sen.cmt: ここでは旧暦を残したほうがいいため、November 1265 と訳出ししてあります。
sen.e: On Tori no hi in November 1265 (in old lunar calendar), when Nichiren Shonin (High Priest Nichiren), the founder of the Nichiren sect, prayed for the national peace during his stay at the Kobayakawa house (which is present Daihonzan [the chief temple of the sect] Jusen-ji Temple) in Washi no su, Kazusa Province (which is present Mobara City, Chiba Prefecture), the Venus started to shine brightly and Washi Myoken Daibosatsu appeared.
sen.cmt: 通常は新暦に変更しますが、この場合は、旧暦の話なので11月のままにしています。
sen.e: On Tori no hi in November 1265 (in old lunar calendar), when Nichiren Shonin (High Priest Nichiren), the founder of the Nichiren sect, prayed for the national peace during his stay at the Kobayakawa house (which is present Daihonzan [the chief temple of the sect] Jusen-ji Temple) in Washi no su, Kazusa Province (which is present Mobara City, Chiba Prefecture), the Venus started to shine brightly and Washi Myoken Daibosatsu appeared.

sen.j: これにちなみ、浅草の長国寺では、創建以来、11月の酉の日に鷲山寺から鷲妙見大菩薩の出開帳が行われた。
sen.e: Because of this, Washi Myoken Daibosatsu was brought from Jusen-ji Temple to Chokoku-ji Temple in Asakusa to be unveiled on Tori no hi in November during the period between its foundation and 1771.
Because of this, Washi Myoken Daibosatsu was brought from Jusen-ji Temple to Chokoku-ji Temple in Asakusa to be unveiled on Tori no hi in November since its establishment.
sen.cmt: during the period between its foundation and 1771→since its establishment と修正しました。
sen.e: Because of this, Washi Myoken Daibosatsu was brought from Jusen-ji Temple to Chokoku-ji Temple in Asakusa to be unveiled on Tori no hi in November since its establishment.

sen.j: その後1771年（明和8年）長国寺に鷲妙見大菩薩が勧請され、11月の酉の日に開帳されるようになった。
sen.e: Later, in 1771, the divided spirit of Washi Myoken Daibosatsu was enshrined in Chokoku-ji Temple and came to be unveiled on Tori no hi in November (in old lunar calendar).
sen.cmt: ここでは旧暦を残したほうがいいため、November 1265 と訳出ししてあります。
sen.e: Later, in 1771, Washi Myoken Daibosatsu was transferred to Chokoku-ji Temple as kanjo (ceremonial transfer of a divided tutelary deity to a new location), and came to be unveiled on Tori no hi in November (in old lunar calendar).
sen.cmt: ”勧請され”の部分を修正しました。通常は新暦に変更しますが、この場合は、旧暦の話なので11月のままにしています。
sen.e: Later, in 1771, Washi Myoken Daibosatsu was transferred to Chokoku-ji Temple as kanjo (ceremonial transfer of a divided tutelary deity to a new location), and came to be unveiled on Tori no hi in November (in old lunar calendar).

sen.j: 実際は、花又の鷲大明神の近在農民による収穫祭が江戸酉の市の発端といわれる。
sen.e: Actually, the harvest festival by the farmers living near Otori Daimyojin in Hanamata is said to be the origin of Tori no ichi in Edo.
Actually, the harvest festival by the farmers living near Otori Daimyojin in Hanamata is said to be the origin of Tori no ichi in Edo.
Actually, the harvest festival by the farmers living near Otori Daimyojin in Hanamata is said to be the origin of Tori no ichi in Edo.

sen.j: 鷲大明神は鶏大明神とも呼ばれた。
sen.e: Otori Daimyojin was also called Niwatori Daimyojin (the Great Cock God).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: Otori Daimyojin was also called Tori Daimyojin.
sen.cmt: Niwatori Daimyojin (the Great Cock God)→Tori Daimyojin （カッコ内は特に確証が取れませんので削除しました）
sen.e: Otori Daimyojin was also called Tori Daimyojin.

sen.j: 当時氏子は鶏肉を食べる事を忌み、社家は鶏卵さえ食べない。
sen.e: At that time, ujiko (shrine parishioners) abstained from eating chickens, and shake (the Shinto priest and his family serving the shrine on a hereditary basis) did not even eat eggs.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: At that time, ujiko (shrine parishioners) abstained from eating chickens, and shake (the Shinto priest and his family serving the shrine on a hereditary basis) did not even eat eggs.
At that time, ujiko (shrine parishioners) abstained from eating chickens, and shake (the Shinto priest and his family serving the shrine on a hereditary basis) did not even eat eggs.

sen.j: 近郷農民は生きた鶏を奉納し祭が終わると浅草寺観音堂前に放ったのである。
sen.e: The farmers in the surrounding countryside offered live chickens and, when the festival was over, they released them in front of the Kannon-do of Senso-ji Temple.
The farmers in the surrounding countryside offered live chickens and, when the festival was over, they released them in front of the Kannon-do of Senso-ji Temple.
The farmers in the surrounding countryside offered live chickens and, when the festival was over, they released them in front of the Kannon-do of Senso-ji Temple.

sen.j: このように鶏を神とも祀った社は、綾瀬川に面しているため水運による人、物の集合に好適であった。
sen.e: The shrine that worshiped chickens as gods in this way was beside Ayase-gawa River, and thus it was suitable for assembling people and commodities by water transport.
The shrine that worshiped chickens as gods in this way was facing Ayase-gawa River, and thus it was ideal for assembling people and commodities by water transport.
The shrine that worshiped chickens as gods in this way was facing Ayase-gawa River, and thus it was ideal for assembling people and commodities by water transport.

sen.j: そのため酉の日に立つ市には江戸市中からの参詣者も次第に多くなり、そこでは社前で辻賭博が盛大に開帳された。
sen.e: For this reason, the fairs on Tori no hi gradually attracted more visitors to the shrine from the city of Edo, and tsuji-tobaku (open-air gambling) was run on a grand scale there in front of the shrine.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: For this reason, the fairs on Tori no hi gradually attracted more visitors to the shrine from the city of Edo, and tsuji-tobaku (open-air gambling) was run on a grand scale there in front of the shrine.

For this reason, the fairs on Tori no hi gradually attracted more visitors to the shrine from the city of Edo, and tsuji-tobaku (open-air gambling) was run on a grand scale there in front of the shrine.

sen.j: しかし、安永年間に出された禁止令により賑わいは衰微する。
sen.e: However, because of the prohibition on tobaku (gambling) issued during the Anei period, a crowd fell and the prosperity of Tori no ichi declined.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: However, because of the prohibition on tobaku (gambling) issued during the Anei period, the prosperity of Tori no ichi declined.
sen.cmt: a crowd fell and を削除しました。
sen.e: However, because of the prohibition on tobaku (gambling) issued during the Anei period, the prosperity of Tori no ichi declined.

sen.j: かわって、酉の市の盛況ぶりは浅草長国寺に安置された鷲ノ巣の妙見菩薩へと移った。
sen.e: The crowd shifted instead to the Myoken Bosatsu of Washi no su that was set in place in Chokoku-ji Temple in Asakusa.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: The crowd shifted instead to the Myoken Bosatsu of Washi no su that was placed in Chokoku-ji Temple in Asakusa.
sen.cmt: set in place→placed と修正しました。
sen.e: The crowd shifted instead to the Myoken Bosatsu of Washi no su that was placed in Chokoku-ji Temple in Asakusa.

sen.j: そして、最も賑わう酉の市として現在に至るのである。
sen.e: Its Tori no ichi has been the most prosperous fair up to the present date.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: Its Tori no ichi has been the most prosperous fair up to the present date.
Its Tori no ichi has been the most prosperous fair up to the present date.

sen.j: また浅草鷲大明神の東隣に新吉原が控えていたことも浅草酉の市が盛況を誇る大きな要因であった。
sen.e: The existence of Shin Yoshiwara (a new red-light district) on the east side of Otori Daimyojin in Asakusa was also a big factor explaining the success of Asakusa Tori no ichi.
The existence of Shin Yoshiwara (a new red-light district) on the east side of Otori Daimyojin in Asakusa was also a big factor explaining the success of Asakusa Tori no ichi.
The existence of Shin Yoshiwara (a new red-light district) on the east side of Otori Daimyojin in Asakusa was also a big factor explaining the success of Asakusa Tori no ichi.

sen.j: 時代が下るにつれ江戸の各地で酉の市が開かれるようになった。
sen.e: Over time, Tori no ichi began to be held throughout Edo.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: Over time, Tori no ichi began to be held throughout Edo.
Over time, Tori no ichi began to be held throughout Edo.

sen.j: 今では関東の多くの寺社で開催されるようになった。
sen.e: Now, it takes place in many temples and shrines in the Kanto region.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: Now, it is held in many temples and shrines in the Kanto region.
sen.cmt: it takes place→it is held と修正しました。
sen.e: Now, it is held in many temples and shrines in the Kanto region.

sen.j: このように酉の市とは、秋の収穫物や実用の農具が並んだ近郊農村の農業市が江戸市中へと移行するに従い、招福の吉兆を満載した飾り熊手などを市の縁起物とする都市型の祭へと変遷してきたのである。
sen.e: In this way, Tori no ichi transformed from the agricultural fair of the neighboring farm villages displaying autumn harvests and practical farming tools into the urban festival having kazari-kumade (decorative rakes) full of good omens that brought in good fortune and so on as the lucky charms of the fair, as it moved from the countryside to the city of Edo.

In this way, Tori no ichi transformed from the agricultural fair of the neighboring farm villages displaying autumn harvests and practical farming tools into the urban festival, having kazari-kumade (decorative rakes) full of good omens that brought in good fortune and so on as the lucky charms of the fair, as it moved from the countryside to the city of Edo.
sen.cmt: カンマを挿入しました。
sen.e: In this way, Tori no ichi transformed from the agricultural fair of the neighboring farm villages displaying autumn harvests and practical farming tools into the urban festival, having kazari-kumade (decorative rakes) full of good omens that brought in good fortune and so on as the lucky charms of the fair, as it moved from the countryside to the city of Edo.

sen.j: 習俗
sen.e: Folkways
Folkways
Folkways

sen.j: 熊手守りと縁起熊手
sen.e: Kumade-mamori (rake-shaped amulets) and Engi-kumade
Kumade-mamori (rake-shaped amulets) and Engi-kumade
Kumade-mamori (rake-shaped amulets) and Engi-kumade

sen.j: 「酉の市」の立つ日には、おかめや招福の縁起物を飾った「縁起熊手」を売る露店が立ち並ぶ。
sen.e: On the days of 'Tori no ichi,' stalls selling 'Engi-kumade' decorated with lucky charms that bring in good fortune like okame (the face of a plain woman) line up.
On the days of 'Tori no ichi,' stalls selling 'Engi-kumade' decorated with lucky charms that bring in good fortune such as okame (the face of a plain woman) line up.
sen.cmt: like→such as と修正しました。
sen.e: On the days of 'Tori no ichi,' stalls selling 'Engi-kumade' decorated with lucky charms that bring in good fortune such as okame (the face of a plain woman) line up.

sen.j: また、市を開催する寺社からは小さな竹熊手に稲穂や札をつけた「熊手守り」が授与される。
sen.e: Kumade-mamori', small bamboo rakes decorated with the ears of rice and bills, are given by temples and shrines holding the fair.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: Kumade-mamori,' small bamboo rakes decorated with the ears of rice and bills, are given by temples and shrines holding the fair.
sen.cmt: カンマの位置を修正しました。
sen.e: Kumade-mamori,' small bamboo rakes decorated with the ears of rice and bills, are given by temples and shrines holding the fair.

sen.j: 福を「掃き込む、かきこむ」との洒落にことよせ「かっこめ」と呼ばれている。
sen.e: They are nicknamed 'Kakkome' from share (a pun) playing with the words: 'Hakikomu, kakikomu' (sweep in, rake in) good fortune, which is represented by kome (rice).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: They are nicknamed 'Kakkome' from share (a pun) playing with the words: 'Hakikomu, kakikomu' (sweep in, rake in) good fortune, which is represented by kome (rice).
They are nicknamed 'Kakkome' from share (a pun) playing with the words: 'Hakikomu, kakikomu' (sweep in, rake in) good fortune, which is represented by kome (rice).

sen.j: 酉の市の縁起物は、江戸時代より熊手の他に「頭の芋（とうのいも）」（唐の芋）や粟でつくった「黄金餅（こがねもち）」があった。
sen.e: In addition to rakes, the lucky charms of Tori no ichi included 'To no imo' (head potatos) (which are pronounced in the same manner in Japanese as Chinese potatoes) and 'Kogane-mochi' (gold rice cake) made of awa (millet) from the Edo period.

In addition to the rakes, the lucky charms of Tori no ichi included 'To no imo' (head potatos) (which are pronounced in the same manner in Japanese as Chinese potatoes) and 'Kogane-mochi' (gold rice cake) made of awa (millet) from the Edo period.

In addition to the rakes, the lucky charms of Tori no ichi included 'To no imo' (head potatos) (which are pronounced in the same manner in Japanese as Chinese potatoes) and 'Kogane-mochi' (gold rice cake) made of awa (millet) from the Edo period.

sen.j: 頭の芋は頭（かしら）になって出世する、芋は子芋を数多く付ける事から子宝に恵まれるとされた。
sen.e: It was believed that To no imo gave you success in life by making you a head because of the letter 'To' (the head) of 'To no imo' and blessed you with children because of many baby potatoes they bore.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: It was believed that To no imo gave you success in life by making you a head because of the letter 'To' (the head) of 'To no imo,' and blessed you with children because of many baby potatoes they bore.
sen.cmt: カンマを挿入しました。
sen.e: It was believed that To no imo gave you success in life by making you a head because of the letter 'To' (the head) of 'To no imo,' and blessed you with children because of many baby potatoes they bore.

sen.j: 一方、黄金餅は金持ちになれるといわれた。
sen.e: On the other hand, Kogane-mochi was said to give you a fortune.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: On the other hand, Kogane-mochi was said to give you a fortune.
On the other hand, Kogane-mochi was said to give you a fortune.

sen.j: しかし幕末頃から売られるようになった「切り山椒」が黄金餅に変わって市の縁起物となり現在にいたっている。
sen.e: However, 'Kirizansho' (rice cake made from a mixture of sugar, powered Japanese pepper, and rice flour), which began to be sold around the last days of the Tokugawa shogunate, replaced Kogane-mochi and became the lucky charm of the fair.

However, 'Kirizansho' (rice cake made from a mixture of sugar, powdered Japanese pepper, and rice flour), which began to be sold around the last days of the Tokugawa shogunate, replaced Kogane-mochi and became the lucky charm of the fair up to now.
sen.cmt: powered→powdered,became→has become, ”現在に至っている”という部分を補いました。
sen.e: However, 'Kirizansho' (rice cake made from a mixture of sugar, powdered Japanese pepper, and rice flour), which began to be sold around the last days of the Tokugawa shogunate, replaced Kogane-mochi and became the lucky charm of the fair up to now.

sen.j: 本格的な寒さを迎えるこの時期、これを食べれば風邪を引かないといわれる。
sen.e: It is said that eating it prevents catching cold in this glacial season.
It is said that eating it prevents catching cold in this glacial season.
It is said that eating it prevents catching cold in this glacial season.

sen.j: 縁起物の代表である熊手は、鷲が獲物をわしづかみすることになぞらえ、その爪を模したともいわれる。
sen.e: A rake, which is a typical lucky charm, is said to be modeled on the nail of an eagle, copying the image of an eagle clutching its prey.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: A rake, which is a typical lucky charm, is said to be also modeled on the claws of an eagle, copying the image of an eagle clutching its prey.
sen.cmt: also を挿入しました。 nail→claws
sen.e: A rake, which is a typical lucky charm, is said to be also modeled on the claws of an eagle, copying the image of an eagle clutching its prey.

sen.j: そして、福徳をかき集める、鷲づかむという意味が込められている。
sen.e: And it implies raking in and grabbing fortune and happiness.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: And it implies raking in and grabbing fortune and happiness.
And it implies raking in and grabbing fortune and happiness.

sen.j: 熊手は熊手商と買った（勝った）、まけた（負けた）と気っ風の良いやり取りを楽しんで買うものとされる。
sen.e: A rake is bought with a smart and fun exchange of words -- 'katta' which has two different meanings, 'bought' and 'won,' depending on the Chinese character used and 'maketa' which likewise has two different meanings, 'reduced' and 'lost' -- with the rake dealer.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: A rake is bought with a smart and fun exchange of words -- 'katta' which has two different meanings, 'bought' and 'won,' and 'maketa' which likewise has two different meanings, 'reduced' and 'lost' -- with the rake dealer.
sen.cmt: （指示書に「新たな情報の追加を避け」に従い）depending on the Chinese character used を削除しました。
sen.e: A rake is bought with a smart and fun exchange of words -- 'katta' which has two different meanings, 'bought' and 'won,' and 'maketa' which likewise has two different meanings, 'reduced' and 'lost' -- with the rake dealer.

sen.j: 商談が成立すると威勢よく手締めが打たれる。
sen.e: At the conclusion of a deal, a ceremonial hand-clapping is energetically performed.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: At the conclusion of a deal, a ceremonial hand-clapping is energetically performed.
At the conclusion of a deal, a ceremonial hand-clapping is energetically performed.

sen.j: （商品額をまけさせて、その差し引いた分を店側に「ご祝儀」として渡すことを「粋な買い方」とする人もいる。）
sen.e: (Some people consider it 'Iki na kaikata' (a smart way of buying it) to bring down the product price and pay the balance to the seller as 'Goshugi' (a tip).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: (Some people consider it 'Iki na kaikata' [a smart way of buying it] to bring down the product price and pay the balance to the seller as 'Goshugi' [a tip].
sen.cmt: カッコを修正しました。
sen.e: (Some people consider it 'Iki na kaikata' [a smart way of buying it] to bring down the product price and pay the balance to the seller as 'Goshugi' [a tip].
sen.cmt: 原文および英文の最後に）をつけました。

sen.j: （そして、手締めはこの「ご祝儀」を店側が受け取った場合に行われる場合が多い。）
sen.e: In most cases, the ceremonial hand-clapping is done when the seller receives the 'Goshugi.'
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: In most cases, the ceremonial hand-clapping is done when the seller receives the 'Goshugi.'
In most cases, the ceremonial hand-clapping is done when the seller receives the 'Goshugi.'
sen.cmt: 原文および英文を（）で囲みました。

sen.j: （つまり、この方法でいくと結局は定額を支払っていることになる。）
sen.e: In short, according to this method, a fixed sum is paid after all.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: In short, according to this manner, a fixed sum is paid after all.
In short, according to this manner, a fixed sum is paid after all.
sen.cmt: 原文および英文を（）で囲みました。

sen.j: （しかし、ご祝儀については明確に決まっているわけではない。）
sen.e: However, the tip amount is not clearly defined.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: However, the tip amount is not clearly defined.
However, the tip amount is not clearly defined.
sen.cmt: 原文および英文を（）で囲みました。

sen.j: （差し引き分以上の場合もあれば、小銭程度であったりもする。）
sen.e: It can be larger than the balance, or it can be as small as change.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: It can be larger than the balance, or it can be as small as change.
It can be larger than the balance, or it can be as small as change.
sen.cmt: 原文および英文を（）で囲みました。

sen.j: （このように、買い手側の意思に大きく依存されているようである。）
sen.e: Thus, it is largely up to the intention of the buyer.)
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: Thus, it is largely up to the intention of the buyer.)
Thus, it is largely up to the intention of the buyer.)
sen.cmt: 原文および英文の最初に（をつけました。

sen.j: 熊手は年々大きくしてゆくものとされ、大小様々なものが売られている。
sen.e: A rake is to be made bigger every year, and a variety of sizes are available.
Rakes are to be made bigger every year, and a variety of sizes are available.
sen.cmt: A rake is→Rakes are と修正しました。
sen.e: Rakes are to be made bigger every year, and a variety of sizes are available.

sen.j: 三の酉
sen.e: San no tori (the third Day of the Cock)
San no tori (the third Day of the Cock)
San no tori (the third Day of the Cock)

sen.j: 「酉の日」は、毎日に干支を当てて定める日付け法で、「酉」に当たる日のこと。
sen.e: "Tori no hi" is the date that corresponds to 'Tori' (the Cock) in the dating method that applies each of eto (the twelve Chinese zodiac signs) to each day of the year.
"Tori no hi" is the date that corresponds to 'Tori' (the Cock) in the dating method that applies each of eto (the twelve Chinese zodiac signs) to each day of the year.
"Tori no hi" is the date that corresponds to 'Tori' (the Cock) in the dating method that applies each of eto (the twelve Chinese zodiac signs) to each day of the year.

sen.j: これは、12日おきに巡ってくる。
sen.e: It repeats every 12 days.
It repeats every 12 days.
It repeats every 12 days.

sen.j: ひと月は30日なので、日の巡り合わせにより、11月の酉の日は2回の年と3回の年がある。
sen.e: Since there are thirty days per month, there can be two or three Tori no hi in November, depending on the first sign of the month.
Since there are 30 days per month, there can be 2 or 3 Tori no hi in November, depending on the first sign of the month.
Since there are 30 days per month, there can be 2 or 3 Tori no hi in November, depending on the first sign of the month.

sen.j: 初酉を「一の酉」、次を「二の酉」、3番目を「三の酉」と言う。
sen.e: Hatsutori (the first Day of the Cock) is called 'Ichi no tori,' the next 'Ni no tori,' and the third 'San no tori.'
Hatsutori (the first Day of the Cock) is called 'Ichi no tori,' the next is 'Ni no tori,' and the third is 'San no tori.'
Hatsutori (the first Day of the Cock) is called 'Ichi no tori,' the next is 'Ni no tori,' and the third is 'San no tori.'

sen.j: 「三の酉」まである年は火事が多いとの俗説がある。
sen.e: According to a popular tradition, many fires break out during the year that has up to 'San no tori.'
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: According to a common saying, many fires break out during the year that has up to 'San no tori.'
According to a common saying, many fires break out during the year that has up to 'San no tori.'

sen.j: その年の11月から歳末にかけて、社会一般で火事に気をつけることがよく言われる。
sen.e: The general public is often told to take precautions against fires between November and the end of the year.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処。
sen.e: The general public is often told to take precautions against fires between November and the end of the year.
The general public is often told to take precautions against fires between November and the end of the year.

sen.j: 余談だがその年には熊手商の多くは縁起熊手に「火の用心」のシールを貼って売りだす。
sen.e: Incidentally, most kumade merchants sell engi-kumade with the sticker of 'Hi no yojin' (watch out for fire) in those years.
In addition, most kumade merchants sell engi-kumade with the sticker of 'Hi no yojin' (watch out for fire) in those years.
sen.cmt: Incidentally→In addition と修正しました。
sen.e: In addition, most kumade merchants sell engi-kumade with the sticker of 'Hi no yojin' (watch out for fire) in those years.

sen.j: なお、2006年（平成18年）11月の酉の日は、4日、16日、28日の3回で、三の酉まであった。
sen.e: There were three Days of the Cock -- 4th, 16th, and 28th -- up to San no tori in November 2006.
There were three Days of the Cock in November 2006, as 4th, 16th, and 28th which was up to San no tori.
sen.cmt: 文中をよりスムースに修正しました。
sen.e: There were three Days of the Cock in November 2006, as 4th, 16th, and 28th which was up to San no tori.
The Days of the Cock were 5th (Wednesday), 17th (Monday), and 29th (Saturday) in November 2008.
The Days of the Cock were 5th (Wednesday), 17th (Monday), and 29th (Saturday) in November 2008.
The Days of the Cock were 5th (Wednesday), 17th (Monday), and 29th (Saturday) in November 2008.
